title: 111_s1381
content: The Small Business Tax Relief Act of 2009, also known as the Act, amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It includes a permanent increase in limitations on expensing certain depreciable business assets. The Small Business Tax Relief Act of 2009 amends section 179 of the Internal Revenue Code by increasing the limitations on expensing certain depreciable business assets. The changes include raising the limits to $500,000 and $2,000,000, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2008. The Small Business Tax Relief Act of 2009 increases the limitations on expensing certain depreciable business assets to $500,000 and $2,000,000 for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2008. SEC. 3. MODIFICATION OF CORPORATE INCOME TAX RATES. The tax rates for different levels of taxable income are amended under section 11(b). The tax imposed is 15% for income up to $1,000,000, 25% for income between $1,000,000 and $1,500,000, 34% for income between $1,500,000 and $10,000,000, and 35% for income exceeding $10,000,000. For corporations with income over $2,000,000, a different tax calculation applies. The tax rates for different levels of taxable income are amended under section 11(b). For taxable years beginning after December 31, 2009, the tax determined for corporations with income exceeding $15,000,000 shall be increased by 5% of the excess or $235,000, and an additional amount equal to 3% of the excess or $100,000. SEC. 4. General business credits for eligible small businesses exempt from alternative minimum tax. SEC. 4 amends Section 38(c) by adding special rules for eligible small business credits, treating tentative minimum tax as zero and modifying the limitation under paragraph (1). The term 'eligible small business credits' refers to specific credits listed in subsection (b) for eligible small businesses, which are not considered under certain paragraphs. An 'eligible small business' is defined for each taxable year. The amendments made by this section apply to eligible small businesses with gross receipts over $50,000,000 for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2009. SEC. 5. General business credits of eligible small businesses carried back 5 years. SEC. 5 amends Section 39(a) to allow eligible small business credits to be carried back 5 years separately from other business credits. Section 39(a) is amended to allow eligible small business credits to be carried back 5 years separately from other business credits. Additionally, adjustments are made to the taxable years for certain provisions within the section. The amendments made by this section apply to credits in taxable years starting after December 31, 2009. SEC. 6. DEDUCTION FOR ELIGIBLE SMALL BUSINESS INCOME. The deduction for eligible small business income allows for a deduction equal to 9 percent of qualified production activities income or taxable income, and 20 percent for eligible small businesses beginning after 2009. The new amendment adds a definition for "eligible small business" and "eligible small business income" under Section 199. Eligible small business income is the excess income attributable to the actual business operations. The new amendment defines "eligible small business income" as income from a trade or business within the US that is not passive income, minus the cost of goods sold and other allocable expenses. The new amendment excludes certain types of income from being considered as eligible small business income, such as income from specific types of property, professional sports teams, certain trades or businesses, and properties requiring record maintenance under section 2257. The amendment excludes certain income types from being eligible small business income, including income from specific properties and businesses requiring record maintenance under section 2257 of title 18, United States Code. Allocation rules apply, and special rules similar to subsection (d) are in effect. Section 199(a)(2) is amended, and the changes apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2009. SEC. 7 amends the recognition period for built-in gains tax for S corporations to a 5-year period starting from the 1st taxable year. This change applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2010. SEC. 8 allows certain small businesses to carry back net operating losses for 5 years. SEC. 8 allows eligible small businesses to carry back net operating losses for 5 years. Eligible small businesses can carry back net operating losses for 5 years by substituting '4' for '2' in subparagraph (E)(ii) and subparagraph (F) does not apply. The term 'eligible small business' is defined by section 38(c)(5)(C). SEC. 9. MODIFICATIONS TO EXCLUSION FOR GAIN FROM CERTAIN SMALL BUSINESS STOCK. SEC. 9. MODIFICATIONS TO EXCLUSION FOR GAIN FROM CERTAIN SMALL BUSINESS STOCK. Temporary Increase in Exclusion for qualified small business stock acquired before 2011, with special rules for stock acquired after specific dates. Increase in Limitation for exclusion of gain from certain small business stock: The per-issuer limitation on taxpayer's eligible gain is raised from $10,000,000 to $15,000,000. For married individuals, the limitation is halved from $10,000,000 to half of the amount otherwise in effect. Section 1202(d)(1) is amended to increase the definition of qualified small business from $50,000,000 to $75,000,000. Inflation adjustments are made to increase the $15,000,000 and $75,000,000 amounts in certain subsections by the cost of living adjustment. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (c) apply to stock acquired after the enactment of the Act, while the amendments made by subsections (b) and (d) apply to taxable years ending after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 10 amends Section 162(l) by renumbering paragraphs and applies to taxable years after the enactment of the Act.
